# Statistical analysis

## Basics

You should acquaint yourself with some common statistical terms.

Statistics are used to describe and summarise the data (descriptive statistics) and to calculate measures of association between variables. Some basic statistical terms that you should be familiar with are listed below.

- Normal distribution. Whether the data is normally distributed decides what statistics are appropriate to describe it and to test associations.
- Mean (a "point estimate") and standard deviation (a "variance estimate").  these are appropriate for data with normal distribution.
- Median (point) and Quartiles (variance). These are appropriate for non-normally distributed data. Other quantiles (aka percentiles) and interquartile range
- Types of variables: Continuous, categorical, nominal, ordinal.

&#x1F517; [A website with description of common statistical terms](http://www.graphpad.com/guides/prism/6/statistics/index.htm?stat_standard_deviation_and_standar.htm)


&#x1F517; [mean and median](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JFesFhraX2M)

### Hypothesis testing

In contrast to descriptive statistics, methods used for hypothesis testing provides an estimate or test for differences between groups or associations between variables. The statistical terms below are useful to know.

- T-test
- Chi-2-test
- P-value
- Power
- Type I error
- Type II error

## Beyond the basics

Understanding of the following, including knowing when to use and how to interpret:

- Logistic regression and odds ratios
- Cox regresison and hazard ratios
- Model assumptions (eg multivariate normality)
- Tests of model fit
- Interactions
